JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken is a surprisingly deep an well written anime. It takes a rather stock and by today's standards, a well used formula of vampire hunting and goes in a slightly different direction. The first thing to note is that the vampires in question were the old kind, violent, charismatic and with over inflated ego's. I found it quite refreshing to see the good old blood suckers from back in the day before they were over primed emo kids that shine in the sun instead of turning to dust. The origin of the vampire they opted to use was also out of the norm and honestly quite clever as well. All in all the villain's of the show were a nice cut above the standard throughout. It was unfortunate that I didn't feel the same about the hero's but to each there own.


The story itself is told in two parts. The first is a form of origin story, not of the vampires or of the hunters, but of the Joestar family to which the protagonist come from. It tells the tail of JoJo's grandfather and his struggle against the evil menace and the artifact that created them and concludes with the legacy his family is to inherit down the ages. This was, in my opinion, the best part of the show. The characters were better written and there relationships were much deeper compared to the second part of the story. I fell the show would have been improved over all if they had made this part two or three episodes longer but alas it was not to be so. It succeeds well as a prolog and dose a spectacular job of filling you in on the law without giving anything to big away, I only wish they could have kept the pace through out the 26 episodes.


The second and by far the longer section is when the story begins in earnest however. Set around fifty years after the events of the first part we are greeted with the protagonist saving a young man from some crooked cops. From this simple event everything seems to snow ball into a series of completely unrelated things resulting in a battle for the world. The true evil is revealed rather swiftly and goes a little further down the rabbit hole before deciding it should probably try and explain itself a little. It was around 4 episodes into the second story the water got muddy. Rapid introduction of unimportant or seldom used characters and a lack of explanations were the worst of it but ultimately not hampering. Despite all that it dose keep a steady flow of action and story development going, it just gets a bit messy. This mild fault in the writing however was the only major problem I had with the show. Most of the other things were little and nit picky and not really worth a mention.


On a more positive note is the attention to detail in the world of JoJo. I don't claim to be a historian but fore each time period from the two story arch's they remain quite true. From the clothing to the technology all the way to the speech pasterns it felt real. A strong case was maid for this at the beginning of the second story set in America 1938 when we see JoJo being sold a "new" soda beverage. Not going to spoil the surprise but I found it quite funny and well plaid. The art stile was also quite interesting. It was quite exaggerated with lots of hard lines and inhumanly bulky muscles. It took me a little bit to get used to it but in the end I came around on it. I will say however it was a big influence on the "uncomfortable" feeling the show gave me.


So to sum up JoJo. Its a solid 7 from me. Good. I honestly recommend it to anyone willing, I doubt you will regret it. It is quite accessible to all levels of watcher as well. Its got enough action and trash talk to get you going but deep enough that the story watchers will get a good run from it as well. Take a swing and go for gold. JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken is worth the spot on you watch list.

To me when watching anime or anything else for that matter, originality is very important to me. Unless something is well executed unoriginal shows really tend to put a damper on my viewing experience. On another note I am happy to say Jojo's Bizarre adventure doesn't disappoint in this category. As it is one of the most original and most fun anime series I have ever seen. 
Jojo's Bizarre adventure is an anime series that has become a heavy fan favorite ever since it came out. It is based off a manga series by Hirohiko Araki that is divided into parts and this seriesadapts the first 2 parts. An OVA series and a movie later fans were craving a cut free true adaption and in 2012 this is what they got. And with that being said it was an instant hit and I can definitely see why.


 So what makes this series so good? Well I'll tell you why, entertainment. This series has balls to the walls action and humor that almost makes it impossible not to love. The story is a very simple yet effective tale that manages to incorporate many tropes and cheese to amp up the fun factor. The narriative's linear nature is actually not as bad as many would think however it isn't something deep or philosophical. 


This story is essentially two arcs linked together. The reason this works is because the characters are related and the entire series as a whole follows the bizzare adventures of the joestars. One problem however is that I felt that there was too much of a quality difference between the two arcs. Like the first arc was good it was fine but the second arc was just amazing and it was like a complete upgrade from the first arc. 


Another brilliant aspect of this series is the way the action is handled. I mean we all ,I've action in one way or the other but the idea of hamon is very unique and it adds more pizazz to the fights. The great animation also couples well with this aspect and it was just some excellent fights spanning the entire series. 


Regarding the characters of this series all I will say is that they're very good. They were all entertaining and blended in with that macho cheesy theme the series's was going for. Joseph joestar was probably the greatest character in the series in my opinion as he utilized some great comedy and some great one liners. I was also a huge Caesar fan he was very funny and had some great character chemistry with Jojo. There were many villains present throughout the series and a few of them were interesting . Especially Wamuu and Dio. 


The animation was outstanding. Plenty of color it was fluid and as I mentioned earlier it coupled well with the action scenes. ut also had a wonderful sheen and polish to it. However I can't say the same about the mediocre CG present in both of the opening themes and ending themes.


The sound present here was honestly amazing. The ost and opening themes were both great. The voice work was honestly great and it was very funny and the seiyuus really got into their characters very well. 


In the end this series was a great ride. It was very funny with quality characters and an Intriguing story. It also had that great machismo cheese feel that didn't feel cringe worthy in a way. If you want an original piece that has quality to boot Jojo's Bizarre adventure is an excellent choice.

Now before I start this review, I must state that JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken actually contains the first TWO arcs of the JJBA series. I will first be reviewing the Phantom Blood arc, then the Battle Tendency arc. 
I have seen almost all of the JJBA series (save for the second half of part 7 and part 8, which is still ongoing at the time of writing). And I have to say, this first part of JJBA is probably the worst the franchise has to offer. This is not to say that I did not enjoy JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken at all. Thevarious characters such as Dio and Speedwagon did pique my interest enough to continue the show. Also, after reading the Phantom Blood anime, I have to say that the studio managed to make the arc less boring while still being faithful to Araki's original. My main criticism is that the first arc contains an overwhelming amount of cliches, from a Mary Sue/Kenshiro wannabe protagonist to an antagonist with no clear goal other than to be evil. Of course, it should be noted that JJBA started in 1987 and may have actually been the origin of all these cliches. (Regardless, a weak point of the arc)


Now on to the second half of the JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken anime. I have to say Joseph Joestar's arc was a lot more exciting than the first arc. The Battle Tendency arc is really where JJBA's trademark wackiness starts to really show. From Stroheim, the bizarre ultra-nationalistic nazi to the wisecracking Joseph Joestar the characters are truly a delight to follow. The antagonists of this arc aren't really unique or interesting compared to other jojo antagonists, but they still manage to insert a good deal of conflict into the show. 


Finally, I did say that these earlier arcs are probably the worst the JJBA franchise has to offer, but they are still JJBA arcs regardless. I highly recommend starting here to kickoff your journey into the JJBA franchise. JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken is entertaining enough and it will amplify your enjoyment once you reach the later arcs of the franchise.

Hearkening back to the days of yore when anime men were built like brick houses, punching people resulted in them exploding into bloody chunks, and long internal and external discussions on the meaning of life padded runtimes, Jojo’s Bizarre Adventure is a breath of fresh air in the stagnant pool of modern anime. There’s so much in Jojo that, in any other anime, would be miserably awful. The thing is, Jojo manages to combine nonstop, manly action with a lot of characters talking about nothing in a brisk, interesting way. In a world where twenty-six episodes of a shonen anime covers maybe twenty to twenty-fivechapters of a manga, Jojo covers 113 chapters in twenty-six episodes. And it never loses the integrity of the source material.


Jojo’s Bizarre Adventure is a generational saga that starts in the late 1800’s with the rivalry between Jonathan Joestar and his adopted brother, Dio Brando. Jonathan’s father has acquired an ancient mask, which Dio winds up using to turn into a seemingly immortal vampire. As he builds his army, Jonathan trains to defeat his brother. Using a technique called the Ripple, he goes with his new master and best friend Speedwagon to defeat Dio.


This first part of the anime is actually one of my favorite manga storylines ever. It’s very simplistic and Cain and Abel-esque, but it’s so much fun because of how over-the-top it is.


The second story arc is about Jonathan’s grandson, Joseph, who ends up battling against the Men in the Pillars, vampires who have been imprisoned in pillars since ancient times. He must train as his grandfather did, then finally take on his great enemies before they destroy the world.


The plot of the series is pretty simple and is the same tired “Fight, train, fight” formula, but taken to crazy extremes. The training sequences aren’t long and drawn out and the few training scenes are interesting because of how ridiculous they are. The action scenes are just the same, minus the last fight that was drawn out a bit more than any of the others. Expect fights to last only an episode, maybe an episode and a half. It’s refreshing to watch a shonen series that doesn’t bore you with drawn out fights. And while characters talk about honor and gentlemanship and all kinds of other stupid things, it isn’t boring. Other characters are being decapitated, ripped in half, speaking despite missing essential body parts, and generally becoming gory messes, which typically enlivens any speech.


There are lots of soap opera moments that end with lots of crying and lessons about things that normal human beings don’t have to worry about because we don’t follow the code of warrior honor, but these just add charm. If the writing had been good, these scenes wouldn’t have been worth it.


If the writing had been good, the anime wouldn’t have been worth watching.


Jojo doesn’t take itself seriously in the least and actually comes across as almost a parody of the macho manly-man anime of the eighties and nineties. At first I thought the writers were attempting to emulate the speaking of English people one hundred years ago, but then I realized they were just screwing with me. The writing is so fantastically bad that it has to be seen to be believed. It’s as operatically dramatic as you’d want, while also bursting with hilarious phrases and words. “We’re not chums anymore Jojo.” “I’ve piddled my pantaloons.” Stuff like that.


The characters are all just as ridiculous as the plot and writing. None of them have much character but the Jojo’s are the selfless, self-sacrificing heroes who will do anything to protect honor and friendship and all that good shit. All the women are just loud, dumb, useless girls except for one, who the bad guys treat as a man anyway and is given a pointless bath scene. Any badass girl must have a bath scene if she is not shown in some sort of sexual position. Just look at Revy in Black Lagoon. She didn’t wear much, sure, but she wasn’t ever sexualized. Until a bath scene.


Maybe it’s supposed to show that these women can be vulnerable?


Or maybe it’s just tits because there’s a quota that needs to be met.


The animation is pretty much as retro as the rest of the anime. Lots of hard lines, big biceps, and fight scenes that don’t run fluidly but instead cut to still shots of punches or loop the same punch animation. Despite that, the look and style actually give it a lot of character. I liked it.


Musically, goddam was Jojo phenomenal. The first opening is cheesy as fuck but so good. The second opening isn’t quite as great, but then you get the ending. Roundabout by Yes.


Let me say that again:


ROUNDABOUT BY YES!


An actual licensed English classic closes every episode and damn is that awesome. I love the song, so it was a great surprise to hear it close out Jojo. The choice of song comes from Jojo’s creator, a huge fan of American music. This is easily seen in the song choice as well as the names of the characters, almost all of whom are named after American bands, songs, or band members. From Speedwagon to Tong Pheti to Lisa Lisa, Jojo is so full of references you can fill a whole page pointing them all out. Catching them all is a fun game and the naming choices also enhance the show beyond a shadow of a doubt.


Jojo just has so much style. From the music to the character design to the way the characters do weird ballerina stances to the names to the animation…everything about this show leaks a long-lost style that will never again be captured. This anime stands out specifically for being so stylized, unclean, and manly. Anime needed Jojo right about now.


Heroes of modern anime are pussies like Eren from Attack on Titan or Kirito from Sword Art Online. Lanky little bitches who never cease to bore the crap out of me. Joseph and Jonathan are the opposite, giant men who only shed tears when reminiscing on the manliness of their fellow comrades.


Jojo is the kind of injection anime needs.  It’s an injection of testosterone that seems to be lacking from pretty much every title of the past ten years. Anime has grown up in a lot of areas but seems to have regressed in a lot of others, especially as far as characters go. The characters have to be more relatable so, inevitably, become whiny teenagers. But what studios don’t seem to recognize is that there is a goodly population of older anime fans who want to watch something that isn’t full of angst.


Jojo isn’t full of angst. It’s full of motherfucking man juice.

To any anime viewer: I say watch this series. It follows the manga perfectly to a T, it's pace is perfect, and everything else about it is executed perfectly.

This is my first time watching "Jojo's Bizarre Adventure", and I really loved it. This series contains a Part I and Part II, both of which are necessary in order to explain the Jojo universe's history, power dynamic, and sets the foundation of the Joestar legacy. The show's best feature is its strong aesthetic expression.  
The character designs and their movement are dynamic and expressive, which is necessary for an action-packed anime. My favorite part about "Jojo's Bizarre Adventure" is the way the entire color palette changes as the mood does. The color is as dynamic as the movement, emotion, and expression. It couldswitch between the Cannon palette, its complementary colors, its negative palette, and radiant neon palettes, etc. This is a big way the show stays visually exciting.


Part I and Part II should be treated as separate plots, and the two protagonists, although from the same kin, are well-established as different people. Although they share some qualities, such as a sense of justice and a very strong will, they have unique characteristics and methods of fighting that are different from the other. The former has a well-developed quest for vengeance, and the latter has the quest to defend his loved ones. The former has strength and discipline, and the latter is quick-witted and eclectic.


Both Part I and Part II protagonists embody the standard Warrior archetype. This is comparable to the trials and tribulations of a strong male hero like Odysseus. Both heroes have admirable mentors, each distinct and likable. There are also enjoyable training montages, and a noticeable development in strength. There are a handful of interesting companions, but a huge majority of supporting characters are very one-dimensional and bland.


My main qualm with Jojo, and shows like this in general, is that their inner struggle isn't something that is easy to empathize with. It's easy to bet on the hero, and it's a straightforward Good vs. Evil development. Although it isn't the main focus of the show, it's important to note. The plot is passable. It's poorly executed, and wantonly explained by a random narrator. The plot essentially exists as a side dish to the main course. The standard for character development set by Part I was decent, but its successor in Part II had barely (if any) character development. It leaves the viewer feeling less-invested in the protagonist's quest for victory and less afraid of the antagonists. It is easy to take the protagonist's ability and resilience for granted, because pain also doesn't have any 'true' consequences.


The protagonist having the Last Gasp Victory a ton of times before it finally happens leaves the viewer feeling mistrustful of the narrative. This complaint is also applicable to the antagonists and their upgrade from "super", to "ultra super" to "super mega ultra deluxe". Which is totally okay, if the viewer manages to catch the humor in that.


The over-the-top ridiculousness of "Jojo's Bizzare Adventure" was a quality I really enjoyed. The dialogue, the way characters move (walk, pose, fight), and the character design, paired with subtle and tasteful hints at its irony were really amusing and extremely well-executed. 


I highly recommend this show for people who enjoy watching action-packed scenes, enjoy visually pleasing anime, admire strong male characters, and find humor in drama/over-reacting.


I had a lot of fun watching this show for the first time, and I look forward to watching the other parts of "Jojo's Bizzare Adventure".

I'm not going to very in depth for this review, as I think JoJo is a pretty simple anime to describe. It's definitely a hit-or-miss for most anime viewers, and I can happily report that it was a hit with me.
STORY - 5/10
Most of the show's watch-worthyness comes from the "enjoyment section", and has very little presence in the story. Objectively speaking, the show doesn't have a very good plot. There are two parts to Season 1 of JoJo, Phantom Blood and Battle Tendency. I definitely preferred Phantom Blood, but that was mainly due to the characters, which I'll get into later. 
One of themain problems in both parts is the amount of exposition dumping used to provide back stories and explanations. The grandeur in which this is done helps compensate, but it can still be pretty annoying to hear characters talk on end with only semi-interesting content. And the content is just that: semi-interesting. The plot is not unique by any means, with two brothers,  one  evil, one good etc. None of that is unique in any sense, but the story manages to nevertheless keep pace and keep you interested.


I will say that I was  surprised at the beginning of Part 2, because I was generally curious as to what the series would do to continue to its story, and I think the structure of the series is really interesting in that sense. I can't really delve into detail, due to the nature of the series, but JoJo is definitely unique in the way that the parts are related and connected to each other.


ART - 7/10


JoJo presents what is probably some of the most jarring animation to a viewer like me, used to the standard styles of all the main studios. I've watched the Ping Pong Animations, the Monogatari series etc, so I am definitely open to alternate styles in delivery, but I was still taken aback by the character designs and fight scenes.


It probably took me 2 or 3 episodes to get used to, but once I was accustomed to the character design, animated onomatopoeias and changing color scheme's, I started to really love it. David Production did a fantastic job creating it's characters, and expressing their emotions in their scenes. This walk the line of "Art" and "Sound", but I also think the openings were animated extremely well.


This is obviously pretty picky, but my main problem with the character design is their legs. I'm pretty sure this was only a problem with the male characters, but each of their legs were small, and really thin. I know this is characteristic of the macho-man style, but it still bugged me a lot. 


This definitely picked up as the series went along, but many of the initial fight scenes felt a bit choppy, when the nature of attacks could have allowed for really smooth animation. This gets even better in Stardust Crusaders and Stardust is Unbreakable, so if the series captivates you, know that the fight scenes get even better (Stardust Crusaders has one of the best fight scenes that I've seen. It's amazing).


SOUND - 8/10


SONO CHI NO SADAME!!!!!!!!!!! JOOOOOOOOOOOOJOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!!!!


The first opening has made a place in the heart of any JoJo viewer, irrespective of what they thought of the show. "JoJo (Sono Chi no Sadame)" is honestly one of my favorite songs of all time, English and Japanese alike. It embodies the personality of this show to a tee. It's grand, exaggerated, loud, and testosterone-filled. 


The second opening, "Bloody Stream" is also great, but not quite as representative of Battle Tendency. From a musical standpoint, I love it, but because it's a bit more casual, it's not quite as "JoJo" as Sono Chi no Sadame. It's still just as listenable, if not more so, than it's predecessor though.


I initially didn't like the ending at all, but it grew on me over time. It was a little lazy in it's animation, but the song was still pretty nice. Definitely not as strong as the openings, but not a bad listen in itself.


JoJo's voice cast is laden with some of the best seiyuus in the industry. David Productions did a fantastic job in the casting of Tomokazu Sugita, my personal favorite voice actor. Famous for a variety of roles,in some of the most famous anime, Sugita is outstanding at capturing the nuances and emotions in character dialogue. He doesn't disappoint in his  for Battle Tendency. He captures the character of Joseph Joestar with amazing precision, voicing everything from his seemingly arrogant nature, to his hidden soft side when sympathizing with others.


Takehito Koyasu, known for some fantastic roles as well (see Bobobo in Bobobo-bo Bo-bobo) does an equally amazing job in voicing Dio Brando, Phantom Blood's main villain. Just the deep voice he uses is perfect for a villain who literally enjoys kicking puppies. He manages to communicate the pure evil that is Dio, in a way that is both spooking, yet comedic.


The main shortcoming with the sound in JoJo is the OST. While the aforementioned factors would seem to warrant a 10, the soundtrack had no memorable pieces at all. There was only one time I distinctly remember being impressed by the sound track, and that was in the killer squirrel scene. Yes, there's a killer squirrel scene. The change to dubstep was really surprising, yet oddly appropriate in the instance. Otherwise, there were no tracks other than the openings and endings that I could associate with the anime. And while the openings, endings, and voice acting was great, the OST is present throughout the anime, and was consistently underwhelming.


CHARACTER - 7/10


The characters may merge into the enjoyment section, so I apologize if the line is a bit blurry. The character's are all so extreme, so outrageous, so... fabulous, that it's hard not to fall in love with them. The dialogue is extremely exaggerated, and reactions  are blown way out of proportion, which is why I can understand some people being turned off. Luckily, this appeals to my sense of humor, so I loved all of the characters in all of their extremity. There isn't much to say, other than they are just a  pleasure to listen to, and watch.


The only character that I disliked was Speedwagon. He didn't seem to contribute anything at all to the story, and only reiterated things already said. I know that this is a part of the show's style/humor, but it was one aspect that I didn't enjoy at all. Additionally, there is absolutely no character development for any of the characters, which is something I definitely look for in an anime. 


ENJOYMENT 9/10


Objectively, JoJo isn't that great of a show when it comes to story, or character development, but the the sheer bravado of the characters, the grandeur of the openings, and the poses make the show really fun to watch. If you don't take the plot too seriously, JoJo's Bizzare Adventure can easily become one of your favorite anime. 


                                                                                                                                                                         OVERALL - 7/10

JoJo's works so that each story is completed, forming a work that must be judged as a sum (although this analysis is about only the first two arcs of the anime), even though it can be (almost) assisted in parallel to each other. Something to emphasize is that each part has a different formula, as well as a different goal, executing it with mastery. Part 1, the first 9 episodes, aims to deliver the clash between Dio Brando and Jonathan Joestar. While part 2, the last 17 episodes, has a cause and effect formula, in which the story progresses with a cause (Speedwagon hijacked, forexample) and an effect (Joseph rescuing Speedwagon).\n
As for the formula, in Part 1, "Phantom Blood," is practically dedicated to building the battle between Dio and Jonathan, presenting the moment they know each other, and the culmination in their battle as adults. Generally speaking, it is a shounen de porrada, which aims to show this specific beating. And in the midst of it, we have the hamon, life energy used by the two protagonists, and Stone Mask, which turns your user into a vampire. These two powers, unlike the Stands present in parts 3 to 8, are somewhat "limited", which causes the protagonists and antagonists to innovate in using them. In Part 2, Battle Tendency, we have the "cause and effect" formula already quoted, which is used by every work, which aims to show Joseph's confrontation against the Pillar Man while disputing the Red Stone. As for the combat of both, Phantom Blood uses a combat in which things like "brute force" are fundamental for the triumph, whereas its successor, Battle Tendency, has a much greater valorization of the tactical combat. As for characters, we have a range that is uninteresting or interesting according to how much history needs them. From the masters of Joseph and Caesar, which are not necessary after training the two, to Stronheim and Speedwagon, who have a passive importance throughout the work, in addition to being externally charismatic. The trait is something admirable, in fact, something unique present only in JoJo's, being almost as unique and admirable as the soundtrack and the openings. And of course, like every good part of JoJo, there are always times to keep hair standing, like the death of Jonathan, (of the) Zeppeli, or even when Joseph throws the (burning) band of Caesar against Wham. And of course, although many criticize negatively, the conveniences in the work are not negative, much less positive, they just help the story to progress. Criticism, like every part of JoJo, does not escape that point. Having a "enough" plot, but with the depth of a child's pool (which does not make it bad), in fact, as a fan of manga from the 80's, it's an admirable plot despite being extremely run down by because of the limitation of David Production, having to adapt 113 chapters in only 26 episodes, which in my opinion, was something bad, making the work "rush". After this, we have as the biggest sin, and again by limitation of David Production, the animation. Despite being very animated in important scenes, there are moments that are detailed in the manga, however, are "meh" because of the animation. Anyway, it was a good attempt by David Productions to be the best adaptation of PB and BT to date.\n
JoJo's funciona de forma que cada história se completa, formando uma obra que deve ser julgada como soma (apesar dessa análise ser sobre só os dois primeiros arcos do anime), mesmo podendo (quase) ser assistida de forma paralela uma a outra. Algo a se destacar, é que cada parte possui uma formula diferente, como também um objetivo diferente, executando isso com maestria. A parte 1, os primeiros 9 episódios, tem como objetivo entregar o embate entre Dio Brando e Jonathan Joestar. Enquanto a parte 2, os últimos 17 episódios, tem uma fórmula de causa e efeito, em que a história progride com uma causa (Speedwagon sequestrado, por exemplo) e um efeito (Joseph resgatando Speedwagon).\n
Quanto a fórmula, na parte 1, "Phantom Blood", é praticamente dedicada a construir o combate entre Dio e Jonathan, apresentando o momento em que se conhecem, e a culminação em sua batalha quando adultos. De uma forma geral, é um shounen de porrada, que tem como objetivo mostrar essa porrada específica. E em meio a isso, temos o hamon, energia da vida utilizada pelos dois protagonistas, e a Stone Mask, que transforma seu usuário em um vampiro. Esses dois poderes, diferentemente dos Stands presentes na parte 3 á 8, são de certa forma "limitados", o que faz com que os protagonistas e antagonistas tenham de inovar ao utilizá-los. Na parte 2, Battle Tendency, temos como fórmula a "causa e efeito" já citada, que é utilizada por todo obra, que tem como objetivo mostrar o confronto de Joseph contra os Pillar Man enquanto disputam a Red Stone. Quanto ao combate de ambas, Phantom Blood utiliza um combate em que coisas como a "força bruta" são fundamentais para o triunfo, enquanto sua sucessora, Battle Tendency, possui uma valorização muito maior do combate tático. Quanto a personagens, temos um leque que são desinteressantes ou interessantes de acordo com o quanto a história necessita deles. Desde os mestres de Joseph e Caesar, que não são necessários após treinarem os dois, até Stronheim e Speedwagon, que possuem uma importância passiva ao longo da obra, além de serem externamente carismáticos. O traço é algo admirável, na verdade, algo único presente apenas em JoJo's, sendo quase tão único e admirável quanto a trilha sonora e as aberturas. E claro, como toda boa parte de JoJo, há sempre momentos de manter cabelo em pé, como a morte de Jonathan, (dos) Zeppeli, ou até mesmo quando Joseph joga a bandana (em chamas) de Caesar contra Wham. E claro, apesar de muitos criticarem negativamente, as conveniências na obra não são algo negativo, muito menos positivos, apenas ajudam a história a progredir. Críticas, como toda parte de JoJo, desse ponto não escapa. Tendo um plot, "suficiente", mas com a profundidade de uma piscina de criança (o que não o faz ruim), na verdade, como um fã de mangás da década de 80, é um plot admirável, apesar de ser extremamente corrido por causa da limitação da David Production, tendo de adaptar 113 capítulos em apenas 26 episódios, o que ao meu ver, foi sim algo ruim, tornando a obra "rushada". Após isso, temos como maior pecado, e novamente por limitação da David Production, a animação. Apesar de ser bem animado em cenas importantes, há momentos que são detalhadíssimos no mangá, entretanto, são "meh" por causa da animação. De toda forma, foi uma boa tentativa por parte da David Productions sendo a melhor adaptação de PB e BT até o momento.

This is an epic show that everyone should watch. Despite the rather lacking first part the amazingl second part makes up for it. The story of JoJo is one that spans many generations. This "season" covers the first two parts of JoJo.
Story: 9
Our first protagonist is Jonathan Joestar AKA JoJo. He is a true English gentleman who believes in justice. After previous events the Joestar household is getting a new inhabitant in form of DIO who's father rescued the head of the household, George Joestar. JoJo initially looks forward to getting a brother but after DIO immediately kicks JoJo's dog Danny his enthusiasm is extinguishedA few year's later events happen that shape both of their futures and those of many to come. What the writer of the manga seemingly focussed on when writing part one was the duality between DIO and JoJo. This is what drives the story forward and it is an interesting take which would be the basis for most of his storytelling to come. 


The story of the first part has a few interesting snippets but despite being so short a third of the episodes feel like filler to many and just plain boring to others. It is entirely possible to just skip the middle three episodes and hardly miss out on anything of interest. Fortunately through a rather clever way of storytelling by Araki (The writer of the manga) which is swapping protagonist every part the following part is action packed. Whilst the first part is generally seen as bad by the community it still has its moments and it is by no means bad it is simply just mediocre compared to what is to come. 


Part two of JoJo's takes place 50 years later and they follow our new main character Joseph Joestar who happens to be the grandson of Jonathan. After coming into contact with a piece of his past one of Jonathan's friends decides to confront our new JoJo. Here Joseph learns that an old friend has gone missing and he sets out to find him. Throughout his journey he comes into contact with an unlikely ally, a ceasar salad and an old lady and is forced to battle with such menacing foes as Esidisi(ACDC) and Wamuu(Wham). It truly lives up to its name. Part two is an obvious improvement over the first part storywise. There aren't any filler episodes and it all builds up to become an interesting story. The characters are great despite a few of them being so called cardboard cutouts they are interesting and they have great chemistry with each other. 


Compared to the manga there are only a few changes when it comes to the story through scenes either removed or added but they don't impact the story overall. David Productions have done a gureto when it comes to the adaptation considering the disastrous earlier adaptations.


Art: 9


The art of the manga is despite being an early work quite good. David Productions did a great job in adapting the manga. Despite working with a limited budget, they pulled through in adapting the original artwork. There are several intriguing palette changes which spice up the artwork. DP also had a clever use of a singular moving image for a few second whilst the characters were speaking. Even though this might be seen as lazy they still use it effectively. These parts like most of the other part suffer from phenomena such as potato nose and others which means that the artwork can look really bad at times. There might be a few budget cuts made but the essence of the artwork still remains. 


Sound: 10


Well, what can I say. Everything from the openings to the character voices and the soundtrack are great. Both of the openings are well made both in the visual and the audio departments. I would like to talk more about them, but it would take too long. The voice actors in JoJo are phenomenal. From part one and two the voices of DIO, Joseph and Stroheim are great. The show would not be what it is without them. They fit perfectly for their role and they are enthusiastic. According to me these were the best but the other cast members also did a great job. Finally the soundtrack especially during part two is gureto. Whilst the two most popular tracks are trap beats the remaining soundtrack does a good job of setting the mood and just all around being a good soundtrack. 


Characters: 10


The characters in JoJo are the main part. Everyone has their favourite JoJo, Jofoe and Jobro. From part one the two main characters are DIO and Jonathan. As I stated earlier their duality is the main focus of part one. DIO being an all around bad dude and Jonathan being a staple of valour and justice in the world make up most of what makes part one enjoyable. DIO has despite popular belief some motivation for his actions. Even though they might not be strong when you look more deeply they still exist. The first installment of JoJo's Bizzare Adventure (aka JoJo no Kimyou na Bouken) contains two seasons in it, Phantom Blood and Battle Tendencies. 
The former revolves around the life of Jonathan Joestar and his dealings with Dio. This season, though being a short one packed a major punch at the end of the season. The first 9 episodes could be considered as nothing more than an understanding of the characters and their strengths and weaknesses but things begin to pick up from episode 10. Despite a slow start, the series manages to give a satisfactory ending to all the viewers. The opening song in thisseries, Sodo Chi no Sadame, is quite commendable and it fits the overall theme of the anime perfectly. 


The relationships shared between people in Phantom Blood are fairly straightforward and in this regard, it fell short of offering the suspense that Battle Tendencies could. 


Moving on to Battle Tendencies, this was a whole lot better than Phantom Blood. It wasn't just all fighting here, it showed actual battle tactics and the honor one warrior had for another. Some emotional scenes touched us more deeply than others and was pivotal in changing the tone of the anime from a mere fighting anime to a fighting anime filled with strong emotions such as love, hate, etc. 


Battle Tendencies revolved around Joseph Joestar, and this part fulfilled what all PB couldn't. Had better animations (to a certain extent), better character development and a much broader storyline. BT is longer than PB hence they had enough time to elaborate on their characters. 


One notable thing about this part was that the characters' involvement with each other was quite nice and therefore just made the anime that much more fun to watch. 


Summing up, if you wanna pick up the series, start watching but decide whether you wanna continue after watching at least half of BT.

This has to be a crowd favorite for sure and I would concur with much of the acclaim by other people. Without sucking up to the JoJo fanbase, I just found this and the other seasons to be quite an adventure. Quite a worthwhile ride at that, and by that I mean at the very least enjoyable to a higher degree than many others. It's also pretty much a show I can go back and enjoy multiples times which is an awesome praise in my eyes, as are the rest of JoJo's Bizarre Adventure.
 When I watch JoJo I flash back to allthe Ian Flemmings 007's, especially with the openings. All that trippiness and posing I guess. I think I read that Hirohiko Araki said Ian Flemming was a direct influence. The art and the music are especially praiseworthy (exquisite even)* and the story is pretty compelling if nothing else.\n\n
 At any rate all you need to know about JoJo's Bizarre adventure overall is that there will always be a JoJo, some villainous ass to be kicked, an adventure to be had and most of it is going to be most obviously Bizarre!

It's hard to really find something that hasn't already been said about this show and it's remarkably hard to explain this show as a whole to someone who hasn't seen it or already doesn't have some familiarity with the memes or fanatical fanbase.
In short, JJBA is one of those shows that's just unique in everything it does. There's never been anything else truly like it, at least later. I personally JoJos doesn't come into its own until Part 3 where now it feels like yet another shonen battle show. Being an older one, it doesn't suffer a lot of modern cliches like tournament arcs ora broody protagonist. This one of the hot-blooded muscle-bound 80s punch-fests of yesteryear. What this show has more than others, however, is an unapologetic ownership of everything it wants to be and does so in a way that feels endearing.


This section of the show covers parts one and two of the JJBA series: Phantom Blood and Battle Tendency. Each can be taken as a story in their own right but really work as a pair and serve as a foundation for a large majority of the rest of the series, where things really jump off. Despite the name, this show has an easy to comprehend if dynamic power system that allows for a lot, but doesn't really go for the "lol random" style of bizarre you'd see in other shows self-styled as such.


It's hard to really explain what makes this such a good show on its own. However, the writing, story flow, character development, and willingness to be as over the top as it wants without any breaks or apology to me is what does it. There's nothing I would call a genuine flaw in the show outside of this part's somewhat annoying tendency to over-explain some characters' maneuvers and plans, something that mercifully gets better after this installment. This does mean a lot of dialogue however. I highly recommend the dub to people who have trouble with subtitles with this one.


If you're even remotely curious, give it a whirl. Just be prepared that if you continue, we're hitting Stand territory in Part 3 onward and that's when "Bizarre" really starts happening.

The change of main character from Jonathan is an interesting way to keep exploring the world and crafting interesting characters. One of the biggest changes from part 1 is the way fights change. Jojo's bizarre adventure is a show that probably every anime fan has heard of. It is, in my opinion, one of the most popular shows of all time. Cause even if you haven't watched it, you know the memes. Even if you haven't heard of the show completely, the "to be continued" meme will crawl into your life anyway. 
So it wasn't surprising that I was going to watch the show eventually. And to be honest, I was a little disappointed. Here's why:
My biggest problem with the show is the pacing. Many episodes can feel so long, because of the fight scenes. The characters alwayshave to stop and explain what to do or stop to warn the enemy that they will do something. I have two problems with this. First, why would they do this? Why do they expect the enemy to also stop what they're doing, to listen to what the protagonist has "planned all along". It also ruins the pacing, as I said before. The episode would probably be half as long if they didn't show us a bunch of exposition at us. You can give information without text, you know that right. "Show, don't tell" is important, but wasn't considered here.


And sadly, that was the thing that "ruined" the show (I still liked it). It was harder to enjoy the show when the episodes were so boring. Cause there were many things about the show that was very unique. The fight scenes didn't consist of only punches and kicks. There was an actual strategy, which is very unique in these kinds of shows. Without the exposition, the fight scenes would have been great! 

I was also very immersed in the story and wanted to know what was going to happen. Especially in the multi-episode fights, where I needed to know who was going to win. If it I wasn't immersed enough, I wouldn't have felt the same.

And lastly, I really liked the style that the show went with. The weird colors and patterns were so unique and cool to look at. I wouldn't say that the visuals were fantastic, but were unique and interesting to look at.



So I'm sorry all of you Jojo fans. I still liked it, just not enough I guess...

JoJo's Bizarre Adventure is an amazing show, and one I think everyone who enjoys Action-oriented animes should try out. My review won't contain spoilers, and I'll break it down by category;
STORY: 8/10
While the synopsis that I read for this show didn't seem like it would be for me, I decided to try it on a whim because of a recommendation from a friend of mine. Trust me, the story is good. It manages to pace itself surprisingly well, and even the few episodes I would consider filler are really enjoyable and added some aspect of characterization to the show. It follows some genre tropes, andit's intentionally cheesy at times, but it always manages to make it feel authentic, which should be applauded in a medium where so many shows neglect this.


ART: 8/10

While the art style isn't the best for a 2012 anime, the use of contrasting colors results in a unique and always-interesting art style that is very appealing to the eye. Because of this method of coloring, the fight scenes always feel fresh and welcome.


SOUND: 9/10

The music in this show is stellar. The original opening themes are catchy and fitting. The ending theme is also, as it samples different parts of the song "Roundabout" by Yes!. The music in the show is great as well, as it uses different genres of music to appropriate the atmosphere and the music is always very well placed. The voices in the dub aren't the best, as expected, but they're not annoying and fit the characters quite nicely. 


CHARACTER: 

Though, after the 9th episode, our perspective switches to another generation of Joestars, the main character(s) (which is always a JoJo lol) are always likable. There isn't a lot of character development, really the only you'll find here is in the shounen sense, in that the characters get stronger and gain new abilities (think Dragon Ball Z). Still, the characters manage to stay interesting throughout. 


ENJOYMENT: 10/10

The only category I can be completely subjective on, I enjoyed this show A LOT. Its's now one of my favorites, and I can't wait to watch Stardust Crusaders and the 4th entry to the series this year.


OVERALL: 8.5/10

I think most people will enjoy this anime, once it picks up, so I recommend watching the series through. You won't regret giving JoJo a chance.

JoJo's Bizzare Adventure is a series that I used to avoid mainly because of the fanbase... (and as irony may have it, I'm now sinking into the fandom) but I eventually gave in. I sat down and watched Phantom Blood/Battle Tendency and now that I've finished it, I figured that a review is a given.
Though one thing is for certain, the word ''bizzare'' isn't just for show.
The show's overdescriptive manner and fittingly bizzare contents managed to captivate me and now I'm hooked.
CONTAINS SPOILERS
------------------------------------------------
PART 1 - Phantom Blood [EP 1 - 9]
The beginning of the story and the ground for everything else to come.
It all startswith Dio Brando's arrival as Jonathan Joestar's adopted brother to accomplish his goal of overtaking the Joestar mansion and heritage.


The Phantom Blood arc is split in 2 halves - the first half being Jonathan and Dio's childhood as they grow up in the same household while Jonathan has to endure Dio's constant torture and eventual mutual peace.

Jonathan reveals his scheme to everyone and as it crumbles down, Dio kills Joseph's father and casts away his humanity to become a vampire.

With JoJo going through deadly hurdles to eventually destroy Dio and the mask and bring peace back to his and everyone else's lives, eventually succeeding but forfeiting his own life in the process, leaving behind his pregnant wife as a set up for the next arc.


Phantom Blood's pacing is extremely fast and haphazard but that's one of it's charms alongside the bizzare characters and great art direction.

While the fast pace made the arc more enjoyable in a certain aspect, it's also the reason why some other moments just fell short, it sucked the impact out of them.


And the overall writing had a few misses here and there, mainly in the first half, as a lot of the issues that were present could've been solved simply by logic (I know, it's not something I should look for in JoJo) and Jonathan just properly explaining what's actually happening and what Dio's true personality is to his father.


The characterization for everyone is as simple as it gets, but that's not bad, since JoJo's greatness comes with it's simplicity. Everyone's based around a single trait. Jonathan wants to be a true gentleman, and his behaviour ove the course of the series certainly lives up to that. Meanwhile Dio's just straight up rotten to the core. He's violent, arrogant and selfish. Although that's something most likely caused by the harsh enviorment he was raised in, while JoJo was pampered and spoiled.

Although as Part 1 went on, I didn't really get attached to a single character besides Dio, Jonathan and based fangirl Speedwagon.


Overall Part 1 is a fun arc with interesting concepts and ideas that were executed properly,

It's got a lot of charm thanks to it's bizzare cast of characters, the captivating art and great soundtrack but some aspects could've been executed better.


------------------------------------------------


PART 2 - Battle Tendency [EP 10-26]


This is the the longer part of the two. It's also a lot more consistent in structure, making it easier to follow.

It takes places 2 generations later, with our main protagonist being Joseph Joestar, the grandson of the late Jonathan Joestar as he gets pulled into events caused by what happened 50 years ago. He's the only one who can defeat the Pillar Men, the ones who inadvertently started everything. JoJo, together with Speedwagon seeks out Caesar A. Zepelli to improve his Hamon, and over tough experiences together, the two form a manly bond and set out to defeat the Pillar Men. As the events unfold Joseph learns more about Hamon and gets stronger and stronger and eventually defeats the Pillar Men, though not without losses along the way.


The pace in Battle Tendency isn't as fast as Phantom Blood's, giving you more time to ease in into the premise and to get attached to the characters, which is great because the characters themselves are a lot more fleshed out than Part 1's cast. Not only is the nuance of the characters a couple notches above Phantom Blood's, the combat system itself is a lot more fleshed out, with us getting an actual idea on how Hamon works within the universe alongside a more appealing use for it.


The writing is more tight and suspensful, every battle feels like a struggle and there were well executed twists that I didn't expect. We get to see the gradual pace and effort put in which JoJo learns how to use Hamon instead of magically being a prodigy at it.


The characters as a cast also have a much better dynamic than Part 1's quickly put together group of characters that have no real synergy with each other (Dio and Jonathan are an exception).

Joseph feels energetic and fresh, he's a joy to look at on the screen at all times and his defining trait of being a cunning trickster has a pretty wide application withing the story, unlike Jonathan's bland gentleman etiquette. Joseph also grows in the story to an extent, starting out as someone who's easier to anger but matures in some aspects over the course of the story.

Now, let's talk about JoJo's main companion during the story, Caesar A. Zepelli, the grandson of Part 1's Will A. Zepelli. Unlike his grandpa, Caesar has a properly presented personality and his dynamic with Joseph feels like a brotherly bond, something that Part 1 tried to achieve with Jonathan and Will to an extent as suggested by Will's words ''you're both like a son and a brother to me'', though it didn't succeed.

We also spend considerably more time with Caesar than we do with Will, which makes him a lot easier to get attached to.

Part 2 as a whole feels like a natural successor to Part 1, with pretty much a similar overtone but much much better execution.


The OST of Part 2 is a lot better, it's used at the most appropriate times, pulling you into the scene even more. Though I certainly didn't expect dubstep, it actually fit well.


Overall, Part 2 is a fantastic experience, with a fun - unique cast, great soundtrack and better writing and is a natural improvement of everything in Part 1 by a large margin.

While I've yet to see what's to come in the future Parts of JoJo's Bizzare Adventure, I can see why Part 2 receives the high praise that it does. Battle Tendency also happens to be the main reason why my final score of the show is as it is. It's simply that good.

LA heard the memes, LA now KNOWS of these memes origins and now already from the first season alone LA knows why Jojo's Bizarre Adventure is soo beloved, yep LA is entranced into the Jojo's Bizarre Adventure franchise and is in it for the long haul. Took LA a frickin' while to get into the series proper and all the more something LA wished LA picked up sooner...
With LA's personal details about Jojo's Bizarre Adventure out of the way, let's start this review proper.
Spoilers ahead...
LA will be straight and say this especially when concerning the splitting of arcs of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's 1st season, theyBOTH have their benefits with the elements used (mainly characters and scale) but LA found that Phantom Blood arc was the best from Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's 1st season and that was because of one character...DIO BRANDO.  LA will say it here but Dio Brando was LA's favorite villain of this entire season, due to the impact and visceral effects he had to both the plot and characters. See LA sees Dio as perfect blend of both a personal villain for Jonathan Joestar as well as major setting villain due to the stone mask and the calculated rampages he made throughout the arc, Dio as a personal villain is ingrained to his personality of being the suave yet bastardly personality, portrayed through his youth, constantly one upping Jonathan in the process and wanting more and more power due to his poor and horrible upbringing leading him to the stone mask yet under the guise being "in the right" and "pure" towards others through sheer confidence. The stone masks also might represent how two-faced Dio is as a result which was nice symbolism to Dio and his craving for power. As a settings villain,  it's the more obvious due to him effectively gaining vampirism-zombie powers and him finding ways to kill innocent people, gaining the army of the undead vampires as well as his grudge against the Joestars being ever more prevalent and him effectively wanting to be immortal and him killing the Joestars being the final link to him being invincible. Dio was and is the best villain of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's 1st season and LA wouldn't of written an entire paragraph about him if it wasn't, Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's 1st season has another set of villains with one character being rather close to him, but he's small potatoes even compared to Dio, which LA will get to later...Dio did nothing wrong.


Phantom Blood arc if anything was the setting up of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's, everything from the feud between the Joestars and Brando's, the Ripple powers and the stone mask. The Phantom Blood arc isn't just about Dio, as Jonathon Joestar has something of character development early on, him in his youth being a bratty half-pint, being born to a rich family, with Dio being in the picture made Jonathan look bad in comparison as he toe sooty rich kid without a care and once Dio gets his hand on the stone mask, Jonathan grows into a more mature and stable fighter in order to save the world, he had help of course, from Robert E.O Speedwagon and Will A Zeppeli, Speedwagon being something of a support character to Jojo whilst also giving us the necessary information during battles, he wasn't useless to say the least, the other main contributor is Zeppeli, something of a mentor to Jojo in the form of Ripple powers. The Phantom Blood arc's main draw at least for LA is Dio, but nonetheless it was a wild ride with crazy fights though it kinda fizzled out by the end of it's arc and "lacked some impact" towards itself as a result. Phantom Blood arc was LA's favorite arc of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's 1st season either way though.


Your next line would be "So how about Battle Tendency?"


So Battle Tendency or the the second half of Jojo's Bizarre Adventure's 1st season, well LA will get to talking about the main villain of Battle Tendency, Cars, yes Cars is larger in scale in terms of Dio, he is also VERY similar to Dio is many ways, from his impact of the Joestars to the plot at large, but in comparison to Dio, that "personal villainy" just isn't there, in comparison to Jonathan and Dio's which strings the feud all the way back to their youths, but in comparison to Joseph and Cars, it just came a bit too late in LA's eyes, but in terms of scale, he definitely brought it and this time it's just not Cars but two other "Pillar Men" by the names of AC/DC and Wham. LA actually liked Wham the most of the villains mainly of how different and righteous of a warrior his beliefs took him. Ok enough on villains, how is Battle Tendency, well for one, events from Phantom Blood arc DOES have effect on this arc and it's one of the better elements of it, a new generation of Joestars comes into play with the new villains of the Pillar Men wanting to become immortal...like Dio!. Joseph Joestar has the similar personality to Jonathan in a ways only he really doens't change much, Caesar on the other hand being the Will Zeppelli to Jonathan's Joseph, instead of being allies straight from the start Caesar and Joseph has more of clashing ideals through their personalities but soon they warm up with Caesar getting the character development while Joseph gets the plot powers honed and refined for the Pillar Men, with that comes in the new mentor Lisa Lisa and oh boy is she important to the plot (seriously).  Battle Tendency has some of the more crazier battles than Phantom Blood considering the scale and stakes at hand and with the refine of the Ripple powers after the last generation, it just makes the fights even more batshit insane and unpredictable as hell especially with how Jojo's Bizarre Adventure takes it's battles in general are like 5 steps ahead of you and amazingly animated. Battle Tendency also covers up the loose ends quite well besides those final scenes of the season which opens our way into the next season but nonetheless, LA found Battle Tendency to be nicely packed, easily digestible, just amazingly awesome in it's fights and how it strings it's plotlines even in it's most mundane.

I finally got around to watching JoJo’s Bizarre Adventure and it was a wild ride, full of fun moments, plot convinces galore and fabulous manly fighting. Also 8-packs. Six packs are the old, outdated standards for the ideal male body now.
STORY: 7 / 10
Lots of tropes and relies a lot on plot convinces (like items appearing at exactly the right moment etc), but if it wasn’t a really fun ride I don’t know what else it is. Although it did get predictable at times, it still kept me wanting to see what happened next, keeping me cheering along for the next inevitable super extra eventthat only crazy villains and over the top humans with ridiculous amounts of strength and stamina being all heroic could do.


ART: 9 / 10


Really stylized, but really nice looking! Made it really fun to watch, you know everyone (males mostly) in this series are SUPER EXTRA BUFF and could easily crush bricks with their thighs. Dang. Also those bright colours in cutaways and inner monologues looked so cool-not to mention the banger-ness of the openings! Super fun to watch as it made the manga come to life, literally making it 3d! It looked like a lot of love had been put into it!


SOUND: 10 / 10


Lit. Loved that I can finally understand the “To be continued” meme I never understood before with this famous bass lines. Also really cool touch how the sound effects were added in the last theme song(s?), made me question if I had been hearing things or not haha. 


CHARACTER: 7 / 10


We have heroic heroes and jerk bad guys who are easy to hate. Characters didn’t really get developed but had the story happen around them? It was fine and enjoyable, fitting the theme, but nothing super deep felt like it was going on. Like Dio is evil for the sake of being evil by having the most perfect power-hungry upbringing with his parental angst etc etc etc.

The one thing I was disappointed about was (SPOILERS FOR EPISODE 23) how Lisa Lisa, the first strong female character we see gets defeated in like…30 seconds and of course is up to Joseph to save the day. RIP to strong women holding their own in a fight when the male lead is present.


ENJOYMENT: 9 / 10


Hecka fun time, even if some scenes could feel stretched out a bit(like a couple of the fights) and other things feeling rushed/not super explained…but a fun time if you expect super extra everything with really buff men, then you have all of that and it’s a blast!


OVERALL: 9 / 10


Overall, the characters weren’t ever developed much/at all beyond their motivations(like wanting more power so now evil and wanting to dominate the world…or wanting to fight for justice so now a good guy etc, super basic). It was still fun to watch them, however, due to things generally moving fast and keeping the story moving if not by character development but by plot convinces that moved things to the next event.

I feel like I’ve said “fun” and “enjoyable” a lot already, but this what this was for me, nothing crazy deep or thought provoking (haha) but once you look past some of the cheesy (and super cheesy) elements, it’s there to entertain and blow your mind with all the extra fighting styles of these extremely ripped god-like men yelling plenty of their lines.


TL;DR

I haven’t enjoyed an anime so much lately for just being “fun”, I do appreciate dramatic or highly developed stories, but sometimes you need a bright, fun time that can still surprise you sometimes, and for me JoJo was just that.

Prepare for handsome men screaming about justice and what fighting moves they’re using in extreme detail and enjoy the explosions of colours and perfectly sculpted 8-packs.

Have you heard of Jojo? Of course you have if you're here, but what is Jojo?
    Jojo's Bizarre Adventure is a manga divided in several arcs adapted in this anime. The first 26 episodes of this anime deal with the two first parts of Jojo: Phantom Blood and Battle Tendency. In the first part, we follow the adventures of Jonathan Joestar( Jojo ), son of a rich English aristocrat. One day, due to past events, Jojo's father welcome a new kid who is the same age as Jojo: Dio Brando, a kid who seems innocent at first sight but who reveals himselfto have a strong desire for power, implying to humiliate Jojo in its own house. I won't reveal more about the story but this is a story which emphasizes courage, friendship and other values but also skills as intelligence: This series is particularly famous for its uniques fights implying not only strength but also a strong mind and a sharp eye. 


   Concerning the art, the anime tends to respect the original design of the characters but has taken quite a few liberties in the first part, due to a very complex design in the manga. For the first part of Jojo, the art is just correct but isn't particularly outstanding, with sometimes a lack of fluidity.


   The sound design is quite good, a few OST are really memorable such as the theme of Jonathan Joestar and, of course, the different openings and endings, I think you have certainly heard a Jojo fan screaming "SONO CHI NO SADAME", don't worry, in a few 26 episodes you will join him to sing together ;)


   The characters are here the core of the series, strong-minded characters, charismatic adjuvants and ennemies, each one embodying a value: the first Jojo embodies perfectly the courage whereas the Jojo of the second part is a manifestation of intelligence. Their names are often a reference to the author's musical tastes. From Jojo pops out a colorful universe with a great diversity of characters and personalities.


   Now you know what lacks in your animelist! :)

This anime is a gem.
Story: 10/10. I've never found a more unique story in an anime. Granted, Part 1 is a sort of generic tale of "two brothers going on different paths and fighting each other at the crossroads", but the over-the-top dynamic of the fights, characters and situations are engaging and a joy to watch. 
However, I think it's really in Part 2 where the show hits its stride with a rather intriguing story and great, unique characters. In all honestly, if you read someone the plot summary of Part 2 they'd think you were on something, but that's the beauty of it: it'scalled JoJo's BIZARRE Adventure, right? And the show delivers fully in that respect.


Art: 10/10. The art is fantastic, and the frequent change of the color scheme/palette really brings life and vibrancy to the anime. 


Sound: 10/10. Great soundtrack, especially the opening and endings. The infamous Roundabout plays just at the right time, and other great OSTs add a new dimension of life and intensity to the show.


Character: 8/10. Some characters are great and memorable, and others have personality but aren't used to their full potential (particularly in Part 1). Also, the characters' over-the-top nature makes them lovable and unique, but at times it can be too much if not done properly. For example, in Part 1 Jonathan goes on and on about how a certain enemy is great because they respect their opponent; this is fine, except he says the same thing for 10 minutes straight and it really adds no depth to his character. 


On the other hand, Joseph does wacky, crazy things and handles daring situations with goofiness and a lack of tact, only to reveal he's been five steps ahead of the opponent all this time. This makes for enjoyable, intense situations while showing us the extent of Joseph's creativity and craziness. It also showcases the type of BIZARRE adventure JoJo can be.


Enjoyment: 10+/10. JoJo is a great pile of memes, tragedy and shounen glory. I don't think anyone can watch this show all the way through and forget about it. 


Overall: 9/10. The only reason this show's not a 10/10 is because of Phantom Blood being comparatively weaker to Battle Tendency. If I had to give individual scores, Phantom Blood is a 7.5/10 while Battle Tendency is a 10/10. PB does a good job of setting up BT, and BT delivers fully with a great new adventure. 


You know what, +1 for Speedwagon. 10/10

I watched this show over a year ago, and I can remember exactly what I like about it. It's not just action, it's not just over the top, it's not just manly, it's all of that, plus more.

JoJo "is a work born as manga by Hirohiko Araki in 1987 and 2012 has come to us a very faithful adaptation anime
 Needless to mention the depth of "JoJo plot", since it looks like a classic battle shonen; we must instead speak of opera characters, which are really worth mentioning.
 In the first generation there is the contrast between the two protagonists "Jonathan joestar" and "Dio Brando." Jonathan joestar (also known as JoJo all its descendants) is the embodiment of absolute good. A man who protects the weak even at the cost of his life and trying that bit of humanity present in theheart of the wicked, representing the figure of the champion par excellence. Dio Brando, adopted by joestar family, is the total opposite of Jonathan. A selfish man who takes pleasure in ruining the lives of others (see the fury that evidence against the main protagonist), and who gets to kill his own adoptive father; It represents the figure of the Devil. The roles of the two characters are taken to the extreme in order to make it clear to the viewer in a more marked way the opposition between good and evil.\n
 In the second generation (unlike before) there are a lot of characters who stand out in the characterization, but the ones that have impressed me the most were "Joseph joestar" and "Wamuu". Joseph joestar, grandson of Jonathan, is one of the best anti-heroes I've ever seen in a manga / anime. A man of unpredictable actions that sometimes depict him more as a figure "evil" than as a real protagonist, funny and sometimes even crazy. Wamuu is a man full of pride, honor where you can see some slight tinge of humanity. Since fighting his only reason for living, he is struck by the words of Joseph, which then leaves the train in view of their future confrontation.\n\n
 Because it is considered one of the best shonen battle of all time?\n
 First, the "best shonen battle" expression is very generalized. We must distinguish two types of battle shonen: strategic and non-strategic. A good battle nonstrategic shonen is considered that when there are good animations, choreography and sometimes even the unpredictability in the outcome of the battle. A good battle strategy instead shonen is precisely characterized by more or less unpredictable and exciting strategies.\n
 "JoJo" belongs to the second category, and we must say that although you already know the outcome of many battles (as said before, the story of "JoJo" is quite predictable), this product will keep you and will always want to know in what so the bad guys will be wiped out. "JoJo" was one of the first works that gave birth to the shonen battle strategy; without it, many anime / manga from the likes of "HunterXHunter" probably would not exist. There are many works in which the presence of "JoJo" is felt and some of them are not even of the battle or even of shonen.\n\n
 The famous pose of "JoJo" are present in "Monogatari", "Gurren Lagann" "Medaka Box" and many other works. The "wryyyyy" spoken by Steph of "No Game No Life" is a clear reference to the direction of JoJo vampires. The coat and black hat Mako ( "Kill the Kill") recall the clothing Jotaro Kujo (presented as a figure in the latest episodes of the first season and starred in "Stardust Crusaders").\n
 Maybe there are other quotes of "JoJo", but these are just examples that make it clear how important it was in the history of anime and manga.

Story.

It delivers everything right to your face, and it is in fact pretty confident about. Right away you'll get, why this is called "bizzare adventure", expect any kinda plot turns, especially odd ones. 
Characters.

Art. \n
I guess, that's half of the reason why JoJo fandom has so many people in it. The main word here is exaggeration. Many characters look like twice as big than Arnold Schwarzenegger, weird posing, clothing makes you cringe at first and battle "arenas" take enormous places. Yes, it is epic. \n
