This is anime/manga history being remade so slickly I can't even put it into words.
It's a teaching moment, on where the tropescame from, on what a well-done remake entails, and on a story teller's (Araki's) development overtime. Personally I find that fascinating.\n
Each arc is such a product of it's decade, for example how the complexity and treatment of Araki's female characters and his cultural references shift over time. \n\n
From my own scoring system:\n\n
2/3 characters and relationships\n
2/3 plot and storyline\n
4/3 for formal elements and cultural relevance\n
A hearty 0/1 for my special award

The first season of the Jojo's anime depicts both Phantom Blood(aka the original Jojo's) and Battle Tendency. Due to the extreme distance in both style and quality between both, I need to do two reviews to treat them fairly.
Phantom Blood:
Story: 7 : Alright, we start off with a fairly simple story of two youths growing in extremely different worlds: one is a rich, pampered and weak, but kind and chivalrous daddy's boy, Johathan Joestar(aka JoJo), and the other is an utterly psychotic scumbag from the depths of London who was raised by an alcoholic father who overworked his mother to death, then demanded booze fromhis son after his wife wasn't there to get it anymore, Dio Brando. Dio also looks like he inherits from his mother far more than his father. (spoilers from here on out till the end of this paragraph)

Then the poor kid gets adopted by the rich kid's dad, where he proceeds to push the rich kid to suicide to get the luxurious heritage for himself. Then the weak daddy's boy grows to 195cm and 100 kgs. Then he beats the shit out of Dio. Then Dio keeps trying to get the heritage and Jonathan keeps beating his shit. Then Dio gets beaten so bad he dies. Then he gets transformed into a vampire. Then an old Italian comes in to teach Jojo a magical ripple power to fight Dio. Then Dio summons legendary Medieval Knights and essentially summons Castlevania in Britain. Then Dio dies. But not really. Then he finds Jojo again. And the story ends.


So in case you didn't know, this is bizarre. Very bizarre. It starts off as a battle between two teenagers, one extremely righteous and the other extremely sick in the head, and it devolves, evolves, explodes, I don't know at this point, into something so wierd and outlandish that there are no words.


The whole thing becomes a vampire/horror movie made in manga after it started as a simple battle of Good vs Evil. It's Bizarre as Bizarre gets.


Art: 4 : Ok let this be said...I don't like it. I can't quite argue the whys or hows. I just think it generally looks poor. It's not "awful" but it's just a thing about Jojo art, about any of its art, manga or anime, that never quite clicked for me.  Sure it's Bizarre yet again, but all I feel about itself past the Bizarre style is that it's trying so hard to look Manly that even the girls look ugly, for one, and for two, the entire style just feels too tryhard. I don't feel like I'm looking at characters so much as MANLIEST MAN OF MANLIEST IN MANLAND at every face. It's just...not working for me. At all.


Sound: 8 : My GOD, this quality voice acting. Voice actors seem to have just the most amazing amount of fun and go all out in the entire anime. A ton of the openings are wonderful in Jojo and the two openings of season 1 are easily some of the best songs I've heard in a long time, especially if you understand the lyrics. While visually I can't appreciate this at all, sound-wise it's some of the best I've heard.


Character: 3 : Here's the real reason I divided Phantom Blood from Battle Tendency. You see, Phantom Blood's characters utterly suck.


What makes a good character can be anything depending on the type of story you want. But the thing with Phantom Blood is that the story it wants is an extremely clear-cut battle of Good VS Evil. Jonathan is a chivalrous, kind, courageous, strong, noble, caring, perfect Knight. Dio is vile, cruel, traitorous, selfish, filled with sin. And that's it. There is absolutely zero subtlety or complexity in the PB characters. 


It's a grossly simplistic and straightforward battle of archetypes. The Ultimate Knight VS The Ultimate Demon. This simplicity in the characters and their roles makes a lot of room for a complex and fast-moving plot, but while the plot and the general story benefit from it, the characters are woefully, abysmally boring. The one defining character maker is choice. Your characters are faced with choices and must choose what they prefer. Well in PB, Jonathan will always choose the Chivalrous thing to do. Dio will always choose the Evil thing to do.  It's so boorishly simple that I find Baron Zeppeli(the italian guy) to be a vastly more interesting character, despite the fact that in most mangas, he'd be a third-rate jobber.


Besides the painful lack of interesting personalities, Phantom Blood distastefully takes itself wayyyyy too seriously. Jojos is a series that I like a lot, but I like it sarcastically. I think everyone does to a point, you can love Jojos, but you just have to raise an eyebrow to some of the more insanely bizarre parts and ideas of it. It's all part of the fun of course, I don't mean to say that I mock Jojo, but I find it to be enjoyable only as a piece of entertainment, as a fun anime. I can't ever take something so strange and archetypal seriously, especially with this art style and the more insane plots and characters of later arcs. And it's exactly what Phantom Blood does: it gives you the Great Hero, the Great Devil, and then they fight in battles that are super epic and extremely serious.


Except you care about neither Hero nor Devil. They just exist to be The Hero and The Villain, and past their roles in the manga, they never have a moment where they feel liike they exist. They never experience or show anything past their Life of a Hero/Devil. And when you care about nobody and everyone wants to be taken seriously, it just sucks horribly.


Enjoyent: 2 : I am very serious when I say that Phantom Blood bored me. I like having seen it for the sake of continuity with later Jojos, but by itself, I can only define it as the beginning of something great that started off very poorly. Jonathan and Dio are extremely simple, the art style of super manly 17 year olds is ridiculous, and when you make a 18 year old battle a medieval knight next to an Italian magic user who trained in Tibet and who always wears a top hat and circus magician clothes even in his battles, I just have to call bullshit. And Jojos is filled with this bullshit in all its instances, except Phantom Blood has the extreme distaste of taking itself SERIOUSLY. And I mean utterly seriously. I don't think a joke is cracked in all its 9 episodes. Nothing is funny, nothing is lighthearted, nothing is fun at all.


I'm shown a guy in circus clothes fighting a 250kg zombie medieval knight so the 18 year old hero that looks like he's had 3 jaw implants can chase down a vampire and end him by patting him with ripples of light born from his breathing, and I'm supposed to take it seriously?

Give me a break...


Battle Tendency:


Story: 9 : The Bizarre goes full overdrive here, and the story style shifts from a vampire/horror movie to an Indiana Jones ripoff, and my god is it better in every possible way. Jonathan is gone and he's replaced by a new Jojo called Joseph Joestar, and the story makes you travel around, befriend wierd nazis, fight millenial superhumans, go through epically bizarre anime trainings, you have fun at every new location and place, everything is just as crazy as before, more even. It's a complete renewal in story style, in time period, in goal, in result, everything is so refreshing, it might as well come from another series compared to Phantom Blood, only the art style really connects them, along with the main plot thread.


Art: 6 : I still don't like it, but we've gone from ridiculously manly with every character looking like some kind of embodiment of virility, to the same thing, but that takes itself far less seriously. And suddenly it all works a lot better.


Sound : 10 : The VA was good? It's better. The music was good? It's better. Everything in here is better than it was. Jonathan and Dio were good? Joseph is better. I honestly can't even dislike anything about what I hear in Battle Tendency. It's as good as it gets for a long-running anime. The only better soundtrack, VA and general hearing quality I can think of is Kill la Kill.


Character: 9 : Aaaaah, the best REAL jump from Phantom Blood. We leave boring and serious Holy Knight of Good Jonathan, and we go straight to funny, witty and incredibly entertaining Indiana Jones wannabe Joseph. The progress is immense already, but then there's the side characters, who also get a pretty big boost from ol' Baron Zeppeli and Jonathan's dad. Caesar Zeppeli, Lisa Lisa, Stroheim, every guy on the sidelines is as good as it gets, bizarre as you can hope it and entertaining every time.


Yet, the side characters progress pales immensely compared to the growth of the best part of Battle Tendency to me: the VILLAINS.


Joseph is a huge improvement in every possible way, but to me Esidisi, Wamuu and Kars are some of the best entertainment anime villains I've ever seen. Wamuu easily earns a place on the podium of best opponents in all manga history. He's noble, respectable, admirable, manly like no other, creative and powerful, and in every way yet has the flaws any honourable warrior would have and he is absolutely adorable both as a hurdle to overcome and as an opponent to admire.

Kars is not as grand a villain but he is still pretty brilliant in many ways and he managed to build an amazing balance for Battle Tendency, in the sense that you never see both an opponent and a villain being fought. Opponents aren't evil or mischevous, they're just people you have to fight. Villains are vile, and that's the beauty of these two: Wamuu is an amazing opponent and Kars a very good villain. 


Joseph, Wamuu and Kars alone push the value of Battle Tendency above pretty much anything, perhaps even the famous next Jojo Arc, Stardust Crusaders. They transform a generally boring, grey, haughty and simplistic battle of good versus evil in Phantom Blood into something immensely more stylish, bizarre, fun and entertaining.


Enjoyment: 9: I honestly would have a hard time seeing Battle Tendency again. Simply because half the magic of Jojo's is discovering the new crazy ideas, and without that, I fear that I might get bored quickly. I'm not as big a fan as others might be when it comes to Jojos. But whenever I remember how quickly I gulped episode after episode, smiled and laughed and applauded at every new crazy idea, every new quip, every new Jojo thing, I can't give it anything under a 9.


Overall: 8 : Phantom Blood should be seen in my opinion, even if I'd give it a 4 by itself(9 for Battle Tendency). It should be seen because Jojo is such a grand achievement of manga and anime that it deserves to be seen as a whole. But I wouldn't make my opinion of Jojo after seeing Phantom Blood. The seriousness of it contrasts so hard with the rest of the series that it's essentially another beast.

However, Battle Tendency NEEDS to be seen. I originally tried Jojo as a manga and started from the beginning, and quickly left out of sheer boredom. I tried again years after due to all my friends praising it, and started with the best part by reputation, which was Stardust Crusaders. After enjoying Stardust immensely, I tried it all from the start again, and Battle Tendency now seriously disputes Stardust's first place seat. If Stardust is more creative, long, and interesting, Joseph, Kars and Wamuu are also serious arguments that make this just as good, and perhaps better.
